linkTarget.anchoringText: Laboratory and pilot tests continued (Meyer). This technique was first tested on a large scale in the 1970's in the Permian Basin of West Texas and southeastern New Mexico. The first two large-scale projects consisted of the SACROC flood in Scurry County, Texas, implemented in January of 1972, and the North Crossett flood in Crane and Upton Counties, Texas, initiated in April 1972. Over the next five to ten years, the petroleum industry was able to conclude that incremental oil could indeed be produced by injecting CO2 into the reservoir and the number of CO2flood projects began to grow (Melzer et al, 2012) as shown in Figures 1. This kind of growth means that the technique is very successful in the U.S.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: U.S. CO2 EOR Production (Taken from U.S Department of Energy)

formatted-caption.caption-text: U.S. CO2 EOR Production (Taken from U.S Department of Energy)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The reservoir has four producing strings and its STOIIP and recovery factor are 91.9 MMSTB and 56.5% respectively. The map of this reservoir can be seen in Figure 1A and other production data are presented in Figures 1B and 1C. The second reservoir is a black oil reservoir that was initially under saturated and was also produced using four wells. The reservoir pressure trend suggests that the system is under partial water drive and fluid expansion drive mechanisms; there is an indication of pore volume compressibility but this is relatively small compared to the other two drive mechanisms.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1A
image-wrap.caption: Structural Map of the Reservoir under Full Water Drive

formatted-caption.caption-text: Structural Map of the Reservoir under Full Water Drive

linkTarget.anchoringText: Other information about this reservoir is given in Figures 2A, 2B and 2C. The third reservoir is a black oil system under volumetric depletion with no aquifer support; the dominant drive mechanism is fluid expansion, supported with pore volume compressibility. The reservoir has been in production with two wells; additional information about it is given in Figures 3A, 3B and 3C. Table 2 contains other rock and fluid properties of these three reservoirs.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The recovery factor results of the simulation work are presented in Figures 4A to 4C. Figure 4A shows that the recovery factor for the reference case under full water drive is 63% while the recovery factor for water injection, CO2injection and CO2 with WAG were each 67%. It is clear from this result that the recovery factor from EOR using CO2 is not very significant probably because strong water drive is efficient in displacing oil from formations hence the high recovery efficiency even from the reference case. Figure 4B which is for the partial water drive supported by fluid expansion gave a recovery factor of 40% for the reference case which is expected since strong water drive improves oil recovery better than a weak aquifer.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4A
image-wrap.caption: Recovery Factor Comparison of the Full Water Drive Case

formatted-caption.caption-text: Recovery Factor Comparison of the Full Water Drive Case

Figure 4B which is for the partial water drive supported by fluid expansion gave a recovery factor of 40% for the reference case which is expected since strong water drive improves oil recovery better than a weak aquifer.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4B
image-wrap.caption: Recovery Factor Comparison of the partial Water Drive Case

formatted-caption.caption-text: Recovery Factor Comparison of the partial Water Drive Case

linkTarget.anchoringText: The water cut results from the three reservoirs are presented in Figures 5A, 5B and 5C while the GOR results for the three reservoirs are presented in Figures 6A, 6B and 6C. Figure 5A which is the result for water cut from the reservoir under full water drive shows that the base case had the highest water cut while CO2injection had the lowest water cut as expected. CO2 WAG on the other hand gave a higher water cut value than the water injection case. For the reservoir under partial water drive (Figure 5B), the water cut from the water injection case is highest while the base case is the lowest.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5A
image-wrap.caption: Water Cut for the Four Cases under Full Water Drive

formatted-caption.caption-text: Water Cut for the Four Cases under Full Water Drive

linkTarget.anchoringText: The water cut results from the three reservoirs are presented in Figures 5A, 5B and 5C while the GOR results for the three reservoirs are presented in Figures 6A, 6B and 6C. Figure 5A which is the result for water cut from the reservoir under full water drive shows that the base case had the highest water cut while CO2injection had the lowest water cut as expected. CO2 WAG on the other hand gave a higher water cut value than the water injection case. For the reservoir under partial water drive (Figure 5B), the water cut from the water injection case is highest while the base case is the lowest.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5B
image-wrap.caption: Water Cut for the Four Cases under Partial Water Drive

formatted-caption.caption-text: Water Cut for the Four Cases under Partial Water Drive

linkTarget.anchoringText: The water cut results from the three reservoirs are presented in Figures 5A, 5B and 5C while the GOR results for the three reservoirs are presented in Figures 6A, 6B and 6C. Figure 5A which is the result for water cut from the reservoir under full water drive shows that the base case had the highest water cut while CO2injection had the lowest water cut as expected. CO2 WAG on the other hand gave a higher water cut value than the water injection case. For the reservoir under partial water drive (Figure 5B), the water cut from the water injection case is highest while the base case is the lowest.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5C
image-wrap.caption: Water Cut for the Four Cases under Volumetric Depletion

formatted-caption.caption-text: Water Cut for the Four Cases under Volumetric Depletion

linkTarget.anchoringText: The water cut from the third reservoir under volumetric depletion presented in Figure 5C shows that water injection gave the highest value for water cut while the lowest value is from the base case as expected. The water cut from CO2 WAG is high but lower than the water injection case as expected; but the water cut from CO2 injection is higher than the base case. It is clear from all three results for GOR (Figures 6A, 6B and 6C) that the GOR from CO2 injection is higher than for CO2 WAG, water injection and the reference cases as expected.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6A
image-wrap.caption: GOR for the Four Cases under Full Water Drive

formatted-caption.caption-text: GOR for the Four Cases under Full Water Drive

linkTarget.anchoringText: The water cut from the third reservoir under volumetric depletion presented in Figure 5C shows that water injection gave the highest value for water cut while the lowest value is from the base case as expected. The water cut from CO2 WAG is high but lower than the water injection case as expected; but the water cut from CO2 injection is higher than the base case. It is clear from all three results for GOR (Figures 6A, 6B and 6C) that the GOR from CO2 injection is higher than for CO2 WAG, water injection and the reference cases as expected.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6B
image-wrap.caption: GOR for the Four Cases under Partial Water Drive

formatted-caption.caption-text: GOR for the Four Cases under Partial Water Drive
